metadata.title: Effects of Intrinsic Pentagon Defects on Electrochemical Reactivity of Carbon Nanomaterials

referenceMentions.context: 45 V is attributed to the redox of surface carbon-oxygen functionalities (such as carbonyl group, -C=O-) during the electrochemical tests (Figure S8).([17]) To eliminate the influence of other factors including holes, edges and pore structure as the by-products of alkali etching, graphene (G) as the typical hexagonal example was treated in the same way to obtain the defective graphene (D-G).

metadata.abstractText: Defect engineering is pivotal to the construction of highperformance carbon nanomaterials toward many energy conversion and storage devices. In this work, theoretical calculations reveal that intrinsic pentagons in the basal plane can contribute to the local electronic redistribution and the contraction of bandgap, making the carbon matrix possess superior binding affinity and electrochemical reactivity. To experimentally verify this, pentagon defect-rich carbon nanomaterial is first constructed by means of in situ etching of fullerene molecules (C60). The electrochemical tests show that, relative to common hexagons, such a carbon-based material with abundant intrinsic pentagon defects makes much greater contribution to the electrocatalytic oxygen reduction activity and electric double layer capacitance. Especially, it shows a fourelectron-reaction mechanism similar to that of commercial Pt/C and other transit metal-based catalysts, and a higher specific capacitance than many reported metal-free carbon materials. These mutually corroborative results confirm the profound influence of intrinsic pentagon defects for developing efficient and economical carbon-based nanomaterials toward energy conversion and storage devices. With the fossil fuel depletion and the concomitant environmental contamination, new energy conversion and storage devices have gained lots of attentions. Among them, electrochemical energy devices, such as fuel cells, metal-air batteries or supercapacitors, have been widely researched as the potential substitutes, due to their high energy efficiency, cleanness and sustainability. 2] For fuel cells, the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) restricts the aggregate efficiency as a result of its excessive overpotential and slow kinetic process. 3] However, the common-used commercial Pt/C catalysts are limited by their exorbitant prices, scarce reserves and inferior long-term stability. With regard to electrochemical supercapacitors, more efficient electrode materials are urgently needed to meet the requirements of larger energy density, higher rate capability and better wearability. 4a, 5] Carbon materials, such as carbon nanotube, graphene and fullerene, have been generally employed as catalysts in electrochemical reactions or electrode materials in electric double layer capacitors (EDLCs) due to their diversified constructions, good controllability, chemical stability, outstanding electrical conductivity and large active surface area. 3-4, 6] Considering the poor electrochemical reactivity of pure carbon materials, many methods have been employed to promote the electrochemical properties of carbon materials. Recently, the defect engineering is identified as an effective method. The hole defects, generally accompanied by zigzag/armchair edge defects, can expose more edge carbon atoms with higher spin and charge densities. In addition, the topological defects, namely the deformation of hexagonal carbon network (e.g., carbon pentagon, heptagon), might contribute to the high electrochemical reactivity as well. 7b, 9] Thereinto, for the pentagon defects in the basal plane, the Gibbs free energies are reduced gradually for all stepwise reactions in ORR, making the ORR process effortless to react thermodynamically. Hence, the pentagon defects could possess excellent electrocatalytic activity and may be the potential active sites. Simultaneously, the generation of intrinsic carbon defects can bring about abundant pore structures and result in the enhanced specific surface area, thereby accelerating the mass and charge transfer in ORR processes or supercapacitors. Moreover, the heteroatom dopants, especially nitrogen doping, are universally acknowledged to be the extremely efficient means to promote the electrochemical properties of carbon materials according to previous reports. Herein, to confirm the effect of intrinsic pentagon defects on the electrochemical properties of carbon nanomaterials, density functional theory (DFT) calculation was first employed. The results show that the intrinsic pentagon defects can induce the local electronic redistribution and make the carbon matrix possess larger charge densities, with a better affinity for oxygen. Importantly, the pentagon defect-rich carbon nanomaterial is prepared via a new in situ etching method of fullerene frameworks (C60). The as-obtained material retains abundant intrinsic pentagon defects with well-developed pore structure, resulting in the enormous promotion of electrocatalytic activity and capacitance. While combined with nitrogen dopants, the electrochemical properties of such material can be further enhanced, enabling a comparable catalytic activity to commercial Pt/C catalysts and an excellent supercapacitor performance. [a] J. Zhu, Y. Huang, W. Mei, C. Zhao, C. Zhang, Dr. I. S. Amiinu, and Prof. S. Mu State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan 430070, PR China E-mail: msc@whut.edu.cn [b] Dr. J. Zhang State Key Laboratory of Material Processing and Die & Mould Technology, School of Materials Science and Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074, PR China E-mail: zhangjian7@hust.edu.cn Supporting information for this article is available on the WWW under http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/anie.201xxxxxx 10.1002/anie.201813805 A cc ep te d M an us cr ip t Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright.
